Deactivation origins and stability-enhancing strategies of Sn/SiO2 catalysts for ethane dehydrogenation Guowei Wang Conceptualization Methodology Validation Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Supervision ⁎ Chunlei Zhu Formal analysis Investigation Resources Data curation Writing – original draft Shan Zhang Formal analysis Investigation Resources Data curation Lanhui Zhou Investigation Resources Data curation Huanling Zhang Validation Xiaolin Zhu Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition ⁎ Honghong Shan Supervision State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, Qingdao 266580, PR China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing China University of Petroleum Qingdao 266580 PR China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, Qingdao 266580, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. A low-cost and environment-friendly Sn/SiO2 catalyst, highly active and selective for ethane dehydrogenation, is an effective alternative for high-cost Pt and toxic CrOx-based catalysts. While the catalyst deactivates fast due to the loss and aggregation of Sn species. In order to solve the problem, complexation impregnation method and in-situ synthesis approach have been tried to enhance the stability of Sn-based catalyst. As for the former one, a relatively stable performance of 5Sn/SiO2 catalyst can be achieved due to depressed Sn loss and coke deposition, while there is still room for improvement. When the latter strategy is applied, 5Sn-MCM-41 catalyst demonstrates the optimal dehydrogenation performance, with 44.0% of ethane conversion and 98.8% of ethylene selectivity, and no obvious decreasing trend is observed in the progress of 18 h reaction due to the well dispersion and anchoring of Sn species on the framework of MCM-41. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ethane Dehydrogenation Sn Complexing agent MCM-41 Stability 1 Introduction Ethylene, as one of the most important basic chemical raw materials, has been widely applied in the production of a variety of chemicals and chemical intermediates [1,2]. Recently, with the continuous exploration of shale gas and the increase of ethylene demand [3], ethane dehydrogenation to ethylene has received an increasing attention due to its relatively mild reaction conditions and simple product distribution compared with steam cracking of ethane [4–6]. As is well known, Pt [3,7–10] and Cr2O3-based catalysts [11–15] have been extensively studied and applied for commercial dehydrogenation processes. Even though, the high cost of Pt and environmental issues caused by Cr2O3-based catalysts have limited their wide application. Moreover, both of them suffer from metal/support sintering and coke formation [6,16]. To inhibit metal sintering and suppress coke deposition for Pt-based catalysts, Sn was introduced to the catalysts [17–20]. Sn, as an effective promoter, has been studied widely, while our recent research indicated that Sn alone exhibits surprisingly outstanding catalytic performance for propane dehydrogenation, which is almost comparable to that of the commercial catalysts [21]. However, a gradually decreasing dehydrogenation performance can be observed due to the inevitable loss of low-melting point of metallic Sn species from the catalyst surface. From the aspect of the ease of the activation of CH bonds in ethane and propane, a higher reaction temperature should be chosen for ethane dehydrogenation compared with propane to obtain an acceptable conversion, since the equilibrium conversion of alkanes decreases gradually with the reduction of carbon number [2]. Therefore, the problem of Sn loss and coke deposition in the process of ethane dehydrogenation will become even worse due to the harsh reaction conditions. To solve the problem of the aggregation and loss of active species, two common strategies have been tried by researchers. Complexation impregnation realizes the well dispersion of active species through the introduction of complexing agents [22], while in-situ synthesis can anchor the active species in/on the framework of the ordered micropores/mesopores materials taking full advantage of their confinement effect to decrease the mobility of the active species [23–25]. In this paper, a series of Sn/SiO2 catalysts with different Sn contents have been synthesized and evaluated for catalytic dehydrogenation of ethane. Afterwards, the stability test has been carried out and the deactivation origin has been explored. Based on the in-depth understanding of the catalytic behavior and deactivation origins of Sn-based catalysts, the above two methods have been tried to enhance the stability of the active Sn species. In the complexation impregnation method, citric acid, ethylene glycol and acetic acid are chosen as the complexing agents. While for the in-situ synthesis approach, mesoporous silica with high surface area and weak acidity, suitable for dehydrogenation reaction, is selected as the support. In our previous study, Sn species embedded in HMS improved the performance and stability for propane dehydrogenation [26]. In contrary to HMS, MCM-41, with more highly ordered mesoporous structure, exhibits large surface area, uniform pore size and good thermal stability [27–29], showing great application potential for ethane dehydrogenation. Therefore, Sn-containing MCM-41 samples were synthesized in-situ to realize the anchoring of Sn species on the framework of MCM-41 and increase the stability of the catalyst. For comparison, Sn/MCM-41 samples were also prepared by conventional impregnation methods. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Sn/SiO2 catalysts A series of Sn/SiO2 catalysts with different Sn contents were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of mesoporous silica (Qingdao Haiyang Chemical Company, particle size of 80–180 μm) with different concentrations of ethanol solutions of SnCl2·2H2O (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Company). Afterwards, the as-prepared samples were dried at 120 °C overnight and calcined at 600 °C in air for 2 h. The as-prepared catalysts are denoted as aSn/SiO2, where “a” denotes the nominal tin content by weight percentage. 2.1.2 Sn/SiO2 catalysts with complexing agent In order to improve the catalyst stability, complexing agent has been introduced in the impregnation process. Sn/SiO2 catalysts with different complexing agents were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of mesoporous silica with ethanol solutions of SnCl2·2H2O and complexing agent (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Company). The mole ratio of complexing agent to SnCl2·2H2O equals to 3/1. The chosen complexing agents were citric acid (CA), ethylene glycol (EG) and acetic acid (HAc), separately. Afterwards, the as-prepared samples were dried at 120 °C overnight and calcined at 600 °C in air for 2 h. The as-prepared catalysts are denoted as aSn/SiO2 CA/EG/HAc, where “a” denotes the nominal tin content by weight percentage, and CA/EG/HAc denotes the abbreviation of the complexing agent. 2.1.3 Sn/MCM-41 catalysts-impregnation method Mesoporous MCM-41 materials were prepared by traditional hydrothermal synthesis [30,31]. 2.4 g of CTAB was dissolved in 120 g of water (30 °C) with stirring. Afterwards, 80 mL of 25 % NH3·H2O was added into the solution. The mixture was stirred for 0.5 h to become homogeneous. 29.6 mL of TEOS was added dropwise to the solution. After 0.5 h agitation, the obtained material is designated as PE-MCM-41. PE-MCM-41 was transferred to a teflon-lined autoclave to crystallize at 110 °C for 48 h. Finally, the mixture was filtered and washed with distilled water, and then dried at 100 °C for 12 h and calcined at 550 °C for 6 h in static air, which is designated as MCM-41. Sn/MCM-41 catalysts were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation of MCM-41 with different concentrations of ethanol solutions of SnCl2·2H2O. The obtained samples were dried at 100 °C and calcined at 600 °C in air for 2 h. The catalysts are designated as aSn/MCM-41, where “a” denotes the nominal tin content by weight percentage. 2.1.4 Sn-MCM-41 catalysts- in-situ synthesis method The ethanol solutions containing different predetermined amounts of SnCl2·2H2O were added to PE-MCM-41 under stirring. After that, the material was transferred to a teflon-lined autoclave to crystallize at 110 °C for 48 h. The solid product was filtered and washed with distilled water, and then dried at 100 °C and calcined at 550 °C for 6 h in static air. The obtained materials are designated as aSn-MCM-41, where “a” denotes the nominal tin content by weight percentage. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The catalyst phase and crystal structure were measured by Haoyuan DX-2700BH X-ray diffractometer (XRD), using a Cu Kα source. The tube voltage is 40 kV, and the tube current is 30 mA. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm was obtained using a Quadrasorb SI physical adsorption instrument. The specific surface area was calculated by the multipoint BET equation, and the pore volume and pore diameter were obtained by the BJH equivalent cylinder model. The samples were pre-treated under the conditions of 300 °C and 1.0 × 10−3 kPa for 5 h before analysis. Temperature-programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR) experiments were conducted using a PCA-1200 chemical adsorption analyzer. The samples were firstly pretreated in a He flow at 200 °C for 0.5 h, and then cooled to 80 °C. After this pretreatment, the samples were heated at 10 °C/min to 800 °C in a 5% H2/Ar stream with a flow rate of 30 mL/min. The H2-TPR profile can be obtained during the heating process. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a JEM 2010 high-resolution transmission electron microscope operated at 120.0 kV. X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis was conducted to determine the Sn contents of different samples using a Panalytical Axios petro X-Ray Fluorescence Spectrometer. The UV–Vis DRS experiments were carried out on a Shimadzu UV-2700 spectrophotometer. All the samples were dried at 300 °C prior to measurement. The UV–Vis spectra were taken in the range of 200–800 nm, and BaSO4 was used as the reflection standard. 2.3 Catalytic activity test Ethane dehydrogenation was carried out in a fixed-bed quartz micro-reactor (i.d., 12 mm) at 700 °C under atmospheric pressure with 2.0 g of samples loaded into the reactor. Prior to reaction, the catalysts were reduced under H2 flow at 600 °C for 0.5 h. During the test, ethane was fed into the reactor at a fixed flow rate of 10 mL/min. The composition of effluent gaseous products was analyzed by a Bruker 450 Gas Chromatograph equipped with an FID detector and two TCD detectors. Besides, through analyzing the quantity of CO2 generated during in situ coke combustion with the chromatogram, the amount of coke deposited on the catalysts after reaction was determined. Ethane conversion and ethylene selectivity are calculated as follows: (1) Ethane conversion ( mol % ) = moles of ethane reacted moles of ethane fed × 100 % (2) Ethylene selectivity ( mol % ) = moles of ethylene formed moles of ethane reacted × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Dehydrogenation performance and stability of SnSi catalysts 3.1.1 Dehydrogenation performance The content of Sn species possesses a significant impact on both the physical/chemical properties and dehydrogenation performance of Sn/SiO2 catalysts. For comparison, the blank experiment without both the catalyst and the support was carried out firstly, and ethane conversion of 19.87% and ethylene selectivity of 88.15% have been achieved. Afterwards, a series of Sn/SiO2 catalysts with different Sn loadings of 3, 5, 8, 10, and 15 wt% were prepared and evaluated for ethane dehydrogenation under the same reaction conditions, with the dehydrogenation performance shown in Fig. 1 . It can be clearly seen that the conversion of ethane increases initially with Sn loading, and achieves maximum at 43.6% for 5Sn/SiO2 sample, which verifies the catalytic role of the introduced Sn species. Afterwards, it decreases with further increasing the content of Sn. At the same time, the selectivity to ethylene remains almost unchanged around 98% with the variation of Sn loading. The initial increase of ethane conversion is probably caused by the growing number of the active Sn species, while the further decrease is likely attributed to the declined accessibility of active Sn phase as a result of the aggregation of the excess Sn species. In a word, 5Sn/SiO2 possesses the highest performance for ethane dehydrogenation in the tested samples. As listed in Table 1 , with the increase of Sn loading, both the specific surface area and pore volume decrease due to the coverage of the surface and blocking of the pores in silica by Sn addition, and the pore diameter increases under the same effect. According to the XRD patterns of different Sn/SiO2 samples shown in Fig. S1 in the Supplementary material, obvious diffraction peaks corresponding to SnO2 can be detected for all the fresh samples, and the peak intensity increases gradually with Sn loading, indicating that the aggregation of SnO2 particles on the catalyst becomes more obvious at higher Sn loadings. In other words, the dispersion of Sn species is much better at lower Sn loadings, which is consistent with the change of dehydrogenation performance with the variation of Sn loading. The presence of excess Sn species on the catalyst facilitates the agglomeration of the active component and decreases the accessibility of Sn species, leading to the reduced ethane conversion. The fact that the TOF values for each Sn atom is notably increased with the decrease of Sn content also verifies the decrease of the atomic efficiency. H2-TPR characterization of all the Sn/SiO2 catalysts was carried out to investigate their reduction behaviors. As displayed in Fig. S2, two reduction peaks in the range of 400 to 600 °C and 600 to 700 °C can be observed except for 3Sn/SiO2 sample, indicative of different existing states of Sn species on the catalyst surface. Normally, the reduction peak at lower temperature is attributed to the reduction of well dispersed metal oxide species and that at higher temperature is related to the reduction of metal oxide in large particles [32,33]. For 3Sn/SiO2 sample, only the reduction peak located at 500 °C can be detected, while with the increase of Sn loading, the reduction peak at high temperature appears and grows gradually, indicating that the amount of difficultly-reduced large SnO2 particles increases. At the same time, the reduction peak shifts to higher temperature. These facts suggest that a better dispersion of Sn species can be achieved at lower Sn loadings, which is consistent with the results of XRD patterns. Therefore, appropriate Sn loading is important to obtain the optimum dehydrogenation performance. Herein, 5Sn/SiO2 catalyst exhibits the maximum catalytic performance for ethane dehydrogenation. 3.1.2 Stability and deactivation origins of 5Sn/SiO2 catalyst It is known that the melting point of metallic Sn species is only 231.9 °C, so inevitable loss of Sn species may occur during the high-temperature dehydrogenation process. Therefore, the stability of 5Sn/SiO2 catalyst should be investigated to make clear its deactivation behavior. As illustrated in Fig. 2 , the initially high dehydrogenation performance obtained for the fresh catalyst only can last for 6 h with steady fluctuation, while afterwards both ethane conversion and selectivity to ethylene begin to decrease. In the total 9 h run, ethane conversion decreases obviously from 43.6 to 35.4%, and at the same time, the selectivity to ethylene drops from 98.1 to 86.8%, indicative of a significant deactivation of the catalyst. To regenerate the deactivated catalyst by coke burning, ethane was switched to air to enter the reactor, and after 1 h, ethane was introduced again. It can be clearly seen from Fig. 2 that the initial dehydrogenation performance can be recovered after coke burning, while the high performance can only last for 3 h in this run, and the decreasing rate is even faster. Afterwards, the catalyst was regenerated by air for the second time. Similarly, the initial ethane conversion and selectivity to ethylene can reach the maximum of those achieved for the fresh catalyst. Subsequently, more significant deactivation of the catalyst can be observed, and after 2 h, ethane conversion and the selectivity to ethylene decrease to 27.6 and 86.5%, respectively. The partially recovered dehydrogenation performance indicates that coke deposition is one of the origins for catalyst deactivation. As listed in Table 1, compared with the fresh catalyst, the specific surface area decreases from 290 m2/g to 255 m2/g for the spent catalyst, with the decease of pore volume and increase of pore size, which is probably caused by pore blockage as a result of coke deposition or the sintering of melting Sn species. O2-TPO characterization was carried out to investigate the coke burning behavior of the spent 5Sn/SiO2 catalyst, with the profile shown in Fig. S3. A broad and distinct peak centered at 603 °C can be detected, indicating that a large amount of CO2 was generated under the combustion of coke deposited on the catalyst. The coke amount is determined to be 2.61 wt% of the spent 5Sn/SiO2 catalyst. When the oxidation temperature is higher than 640 °C, the profile tends to be stable around the baseline, indicative of the end of the burning. This fact further suggests that the coke deposited on the spent catalyst can be fully burned during the regeneration process. After regeneration, the initial dehydrogenation performance can be recovered, while the stability gets worse time after time. This indicates that coke deposition is only one of the origins for catalyst deactivation, other factors such as sintering or loss of Sn species, which cannot be recovered by air combustion, also exist. XRF characterization was performed to study the Sn content on the catalysts before and after reaction (listed in Table 1). The Sn content decreases from 4.15 to 2.70% after 9 h reaction, which means that 34.9% of Sn species is lost during the reaction. In addition, the XRD patterns of 5Sn/SiO2 catalyst after hydrogen reduction and 9 h reaction are displayed in Fig. S4. Besides the support, metallic Sn is the only phase existed on the two catalysts. It can be clearly seen that the intensity of diffraction peaks corresponding to Sn0 increases obviously after reaction. Combined with the decreased specific surface area, the increased intensity can verify the increase of particle size of metallic Sn. The average particle size of Sn0, as estimated by Scherrer equation, increases from 51 nm to 77 nm after reaction. It should also be noted that the content of Sn decreases obviously during the 9 h reaction, so Sn sintering also occurs considering all the above facts. XRF and XRD characterizations have also been carried out to investigate the amount and existing state of Sn species during the reaction-regeneration processes. For the catalyst after the first reaction-regeneration cycle, Sn content decreases from 2.7% to 2.26% during the 6 h reaction, indicative of a lower rate (0.027%/h) for Sn loss compared with that of the fresh catalyst (0.039%/h). While after 1st regeneration, the average particle size of metallic Sn estimated by Scherrer equation decreases from 77 nm (the spent catalyst after 9 h reaction) to 65 nm, demonstrating that the Sn species have been partially redispersed to some extent during the regeneration process. During the 6 h reaction for the catalyst after the first reaction-regeneration cycle, the average particle size further increases to 87 nm. All the above facts indicate that the loss and aggregation of Sn species still occur during the further reaction-regeneration cycles. Therefore, under the high reaction temperature, it is easy for the low-melting-point metallic Sn species to move together and/or loss from the catalyst surface, leading to irreversible deactivation of the catalyst, which cannot be recovered through coke burning. 3.2 Stability-enhancing strategies of Sn/SiO2 catalysts Based on the above problems of agglomeration and loss of metallic Sn species, complexation impregnation approach and in-situ synthesis method have both been tried to realize the anchoring of Sn species on the catalyst in order to enhance the stability of Sn-based catalysts. 3.2.1 Complexation impregnation approach Herein, citric acid (CA), ethylene glycol (EG) and acetic acid (HAc) are chosen as the complexing agents. In the calcination process, the generated gas flow (CO2 and H2O) during the combustion of the agents is expected to hinder the aggregation of Sn particles and facilitate the dispersion of Sn species. The long-term evaluation of these catalysts for ethane dehydrogenation was carried out under the same reaction conditions, with the results displayed in Fig. 3 . For all the three 5Sn/SiO2 samples with complexing agents, both the conversion of ethane and the selectivity to ethylene keep stable for a longer time (11 h) compared with the traditional 5Sn/SiO2 sample (6 h), and obvious deactivation can be detected after 12 h during the reaction, indicating that the introduction of complexing agents in the catalyst preparation process indeed slows down catalyst deactivation and enhances its stability. From the aspect of the dehydrogenation activity, no big difference can be observed for the three samples. Comparatively speaking, a slightly higher ethane conversion can be obtained for 5Sn/SiO2-EG catalyst. In the beginning 11 h, ethane conversion maintains around 43%, and the selectivity to ethylene keeps higher than 98%. The textual properties of 5Sn/SiO2 catalysts with different complexing agents are listed in Table 2 . Notable increase of the pore diameter can be observed after the addition of the complexing agent, and there is no obvious decrease of the specific surface area, so as the pore volume. These facts suggest that the generated gas flow diffuses and exerts some influences on the physical structure of the catalyst although the introduced agent can be eliminated through catalyst calcination. XRD patterns of the three samples after hydrogen reduction is shown in Fig. S5. Obvious diffraction peaks located at 30.6, 32.0, 43.9, 44.9, 55.5, 62.5 and 64.7° attributed to metallic Sn can be detected, similar to the XRD patterns of the original 5Sn/SiO2, indicating that metallic Sn is the main phase on the catalyst surface prior to reaction. Contrary to the original 5Sn/SiO2, all the intensities of the diffraction peaks decrease to some extent. According to Scherrer equation, the average particle sizes of 5Sn/SiO2 CA, 5Sn/SiO2-EG, 5Sn/SiO2 HAc are 41.8 nm, 41.4 nm and 43.2 nm, respectively. The added complexing agent can indeed facilitate the dispersion of Sn species as expected. Moreover, the coke and Sn contents on the spent catalysts were also determined, as listed in Table 2. The introduced complexing agents significantly decrease the amount of coke deposition from 2.62 to 1.41, 1.99 and 1.20% separately for 5Sn/SiO2 CA, 5Sn/SiO2-EG and 5Sn/SiO2 HAc samples. At the same time, the loss of Sn is significantly depressed from 34.9% to 16.2, 17.5 and 22.6% for 5Sn/SiO2 CA, 5Sn/SiO2-EG and 5Sn/SiO2 HAc samples, respectively. Therefore, the introduction of the complexing agent can facilitate the dispersion of Sn species, inhibit the aggregation and loss of metallic Sn species, and finally enhance the catalyst stability to some extent, while there is still room for improvement. 3.2.2 In-situ synthesis method MCM-41 siliceous molecular sieves, with more highly ordered mesoporous structure, was chosen in this part. In order to realize the anchoring of Sn species on the framework of MCM-41, a series of Sn-MCM-41 with different Sn contents was in-situ synthesized. The small-angle XRD patterns of MCM-41 and Sn-MCM-41 catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . MCM-41 sample shows three distinct peaks at 2.3°, 3.7°, and 4.5°, attributed to (100), (110), and (200) reflections, respectively, indicative of a well ordered hexagonal arranged structure of MCM-41[34,35]. Compared with the original MCM-41, the intensities of the diffraction peaks show a decreasing trend for Sn-containing samples, and decrease further with the increase of Sn content. This fact indicates that the long-range regularity of hexagonal arrays of mesopores is gradually declined by the introduction of Sn ions. This is probably caused by the negative effect of the introduced metal ions on the structure directing behavior of the template in the solution [36]. Even though, the characteristic mesoporous structure is not destroyed for the three samples. For comparison, 2Sn/MCM-41 samples, with similar Sn content as 3Sn-MCM-41 (see Table 3 ), were also prepared through traditional impregnation method. The wide-angle XRD patterns of 2Sn/MCM-41 and 5Sn-MCM-41 catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 5 . When impregnation method is applied, the characteristic peaks of SnO2 can be obviously observed, even if the Sn loading is just 2%. In contrast, no diffraction peaks attributed to SnO2 can be detected for 5Sn-MCM-41 sample. The results further confirm that for the Sn-MCM-41 catalyst prepared by in-situ synthesis method, Sn species are highly dispersed or even embedded into the framework of MCM-41 structure, instead of aggregating together to form large particles. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of MCM-41 and Sn containing MCM-41 samples are illustrated in Fig. S6. It can be clearly seen that all samples exhibit isotherms of type-IV characteristic of mesoporous materials and hysteresis loops of type-H1 attributed to capillary condensation in the mesopores, indicating that the mesoporous structure of MCM-41 is not destroyed in both the two preparation methods. The corresponding textural properties of Sn containing MCM-41 samples are listed in Table 3. For the samples prepared by in-situ synthesis method, the incorporation of Sn species leads to increased pore diameter and pore volume, which is probably caused by the substitution of small-diameter Si4+ (0.026 nm) with large-diameter Sn4+ (0.055 nm) on the framework of MCM-41. This fact further verifies that the added Sn species have been embedded in MCM-41 materials. At the same time, the specific surface area decreases to some extent. While for the catalysts prepared by impregnation method, both the specific surface area and pore volume decrease more severely after the introduction of Sn species, which is resulted from the coverage or blockage of the pores of MCM-41. Compared with 5Sn-MCM-41 (in-situ synthesis) sample, the specific surface area of 2Sn/MCM-41 (impregnation) decreases even more significantly. Therefore, for the traditional impregnation method, most Sn species are accumulated on the surface or in the pores of MCM-41, while the in-situ synthesis approach can realize the anchoring of Sn species on the framework of MCM-41. All these observations are well consistent with the results of XRD characterization. UV–Vis diffuse reflection spectra (UV–Vis DRS) were recorded to detect the coordination states of Sn ions. As shown in Fig. 6 , no obvious absorption peak can be detected for MCM-41 and 5Sn-MCM-41 samples. In contrary, a broad absorption band from 230 to 300 nm is observed for 2Sn/MCM-41 sample prepared by impregnation method. According to literatures [37,38], the absorption bands located in the range of 200 to 300 nm is ascribed to the existence of SnO2 clusters or nanocrystallites. Therefore, UV–Vis DRS characterization further confirms that Sn species in the in-situ synthesized Sn-MCM-41 samples are well dispersed and the formation of aggregated SnO2 crystals is effectively inhibited. The influence of synthesis methods on the reduction behaviors of the catalysts were also investigated, and the H2-TPR profiles are shown in Fig. S7. No H2 consumption peak can be observed for the TPR profile of pure MCM-41. All the Sn containing MCM-41 samples exhibit a broad peak within 200–700 °C attributed to the reduction of Sn species. Comparatively speaking, the reduction of Sn species terminates at 580 °C for 3Sn-MCM-41 and 5Sn-MCM-41 samples, while the H2 consumption peak extends to 700 °C for 2Sn/MCM-41 prepared by impregnation method. Actually, the reduction peak at 600–700 °C is ascribed to the reduction of bulk SnO2 to metallic Sn [39]. The above facts indicate that large SnO2 particles exist on the surface of 2Sn/MCM-41 catalyst, and no aggregated SnO2 species are present on Sn-MCM-41 samples, which is completely consistent with the XRD patterns and UV–Vis DRS spectra. In order to further confirm the dispersion of Sn species on Sn containing MCM-41 catalysts, TEM images of 2Sn/MCM-41 and 5Sn-MCM-41 samples are presented in Fig. 7 . The regular array of mesoporous channels in a hexagonal arrangement as a characteristic of MCM-41 can be clearly observed for both two catalysts. According to Fig. 7(a-b), 2Sn/MCM-41 sample prepared by impregnation method show aggregated SnO2 crystallites in the framework of MCM-41, some of which are large enough (>20 nm) to block the pores partially. With further increase of Sn loading, the aggregation of SnO2 crystallites gets more remarkable for 5Sn/MCM-41 (see Fig. S8). However, unlike 2Sn/MCM-41 sample, TEM images of 5Sn-MCM-41 sample prepared by in-situ synthesis method (Fig. 7(c-d)) clearly show no evidence of bulk SnO2 crystallites condensed on MCM-41 surface, which further confirms that Sn species are probably dispersed on the framework of MCM-41. This observation agrees well with the previously presented XRD, UV–Vis DRS and H2-TPR results. Fig. 8 shows the dehydrogenation performances of Sn-MCM-41 catalysts prepared by in-situ synthesis method. The pure MCM-41 support material exhibits a relatively low activity for ethane dehydrogenation, basically caused by thermal reaction. Ethane conversion increases significantly to 40% after the initial introduction of 2 wt% Sn species. With further increase of Sn content, ethane conversion increases continuously, and the increasing rate remains almost stable when Sn content increases from 2 to 5 wt%, which is probably caused by the well dispersion of Sn species on the framework of MCM-41, consistent with other studies [36]. 5Sn-MCM-41 catalyst demonstrates the optimal dehydrogenation performance, with 44.0% of ethane conversion and 98.8% of ethylene selectivity, slightly higher than the performances obtained for 5Sn/SiO2 and 5Sn/SiO2 samples with different complexing agents. The stability of Sn-MCM-41 catalysts have also been investigated to verify the effect of anchoring Sn species on the framework of MCM-41. For comparison, 2Sn/MCM-41 sample prepared by impregnation method, with similar Sn content to 3Sn-MCM-41 (see Table 3), has also been evaluated herein. As displayed in Fig. 9 , in the continuous 18 h reaction, the conversion of ethane and the selectivity to ethylene for 2Sn/MCM-41 catalyst decrease significantly from 43.4% and 98.1% to 31.8% and 84.6%, respectively. In contrary, the dehydrogenation performances for 3Sn-MCM-41 and 5Sn-MCM-41 samples are more stable, and no obvious decreasing trend can be observed in the progress of 18 h reaction. Similar selectivity to ethylene can be obtained for the two in-situ synthesized samples, while a higher ethane conversion of 44% is achieved for 5Sn-MCM-41 sample due to the increased number of active Sn species. According to Table 3, during the 18 h run, elemental analysis results obtained from XRF indicate that the Sn contents of 3Sn-MCM-41 and 5Sn-MCM-41 samples decrease from 1.82 to 2.78 wt% to 1.77 and 2.70 wt%, indicative of 2.7 wt% and 2.9 wt% loss of Sn species, respectively. These values are obviously lower than the Sn loss of 16.7 wt% over the spent 2Sn/MCM-41 catalyst. Given 34.9 wt% of Sn loss for the spent 5Sn/SiO2 sample, the incorporation of Sn into the mesoporous structure of MCM-41 effectively realize the well dispersion of Sn species and inhibits Sn loss from the catalyst, resulting in a reduced deactivation rate and enhanced stability. Moreover, the coke amount deposited on Sn-MCM-41 samples (Table 3) decreases obviously compared with 5Sn/SiO2 catalyst (2.61 wt% for 9 h reaction) and 5Sn/SiO2 catalyst with the complexing agents (1.20∼1.99 wt% for 12 h reaction). Furthermore, the reaction-regeneration stability of 5Sn-MCM-41 sample was also evaluated. It can be clearly seen from Fig. 10 that the dehydrogenation performance can be completely recovered after each time of in-situ coke burning, and the performance keeps stable in the continuous 10 h running. The conversion of ethane and the selectivity to ethylene fluctuate stably around 44% and 96%, respectively, which further verify the enhancing effect of in-situ synthesis approach on the stability of Sn-containing catalyst for dehydrogenation reaction. To sum up, the in-situ synthesis method can anchor Sn species on the framework of MCM-41, effectively reduce the mobility of Sn species on the support, and inhibit the loss of active Sn species during the reaction, and at the same time, the formation of coke is also significantly depressed. Therefore, compared with the addition of complexing agent, the in-situ introduction of Sn species on the framework of MCM-41 is an effective strategy to enhance the stability of Sn-based catalysts for ethane dehydrogenation. 4 Conclusions The present study has demonstrated that low-cost and environment-friendly Sn/SiO2 catalysts are active and selective for ethane dehydrogenation. Sn/SiO2 catalyst with 5 wt% Sn content exhibits the optimum dehydrogenation performance, while the catalyst deactivates obviously after 9 h reaction. The loss and aggregation of Sn species on the support, as well as coke deposition are the origins for catalyst deactivation. Afterwards, complexation impregnation method and in-situ synthesis approach have been tried to enhance the stability of the catalyst. Citric acid, ethylene glycol and acetic acid are chosen as the complexing agents. A longer duration of 5Sn/SiO2 catalyst with complexing agent can be obtained due to depressed Sn aggregation and coke deposition under the coordinated complexing effect. While in-situ synthesis approach is proved to be a more efficient stability-enhancing strategy. Excellent dehydrogenation performance and good stability for ethane dehydrogenation can be achieved for 5Sn-MCM-41, which is caused by the well dispersion of Sn species anchored into the framework of MCM-41, rather than aggregating together to form large particles for the impregnated samples. This approach provides new insights into the stability-enhancing strategies for other catalytic systems. coredata.dc:description: A low-cost and environment-friendly Sn/SiO2 catalyst, highly active and selective for ethane dehydrogenation, is an effective alternative for high-cost Pt and toxic CrOx-based catalysts. While the catalyst deactivates fast due to the loss and aggregation of Sn species. In order to solve the problem, complexation impregnation method and in-situ synthesis approach have been tried to enhance the stability of Sn-based catalyst. As for the former one, a relatively stable performance of 5Sn/SiO2 catalyst can be achieved due to depressed Sn loss and coke deposition, while there is still room for improvement. When the latter strategy is applied, 5Sn-MCM-41 catalyst demonstrates the optimal dehydrogenation performance, with 44.0% of ethane conversion and 98.8% of ethylene selectivity, and no obvious decreasing trend is observed in the progress of 18 h reaction due to the well dispersion and anchoring of Sn species on the framework of MCM-41.
coredata.dc:title: Deactivation origins and stability-enhancing strategies of Sn/SiO2 catalysts for ethane dehydrogenation
